pullRequest.body:
Fix some porting notes about `ext` and classifies the remaining ones about `ext`

---

The remaining porting notes mentioning `ext` are categorised by the issues

- #11182
- #5229
-  #11041

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9695722299/job/26756090455)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9695722299/job/26756091271)

Globally LGTM. I have resolved the merge conflict and suggested a few minor changes that can be directly committed from browser pretty quickly. 

@jcommelin

Globally LGTM. I have resolved the merge conflict and suggested a few minor changes that can be directly committed from browser pretty quickly. 

@jcommelin
This seems fine: `FreeSemigroup.ext` seems to be protected, and that seems as desired.

Yes, I believe you're right. 

What do you think, @joelriou?
I just double-checked this with mathlib3: it was indeed `free_semigroup.ext` that's used here in mathlib 3 so there is really nothing happening here.

An alternative would be, to avoid using the name of `h'` explicitely

```
ext
¬∑ exact mem_domain_iff_of_eq_graph h
¬∑ apply (le_of_le_graph h.le).2
  assumption
```

Yes, I believe 

```lean
ext
¬∑ exact mem_domain_iff_of_eq_graph h
¬∑ apply (le_of_le_graph h.le).2
  assumption
```

is better. What do you think, @jcommelin?
Yeah, looks good to me.
